detail.content: Urban Planning and Design: Past, Present and Future | NYU Wagner                                    Jump to navigation                                                             Urban Planning and Design: Past, Present and Future   UPADM-GP.282, 4 points.       Courses         Description |    Syllabi |    Evaluations           The rapid rate and massive scale of urbanization globally make urban planning and design more critical than ever. This course introduces a selection of key ideas, experiences, and planning practices that shaped the contemporary city, and those that contend to shape the future city. In a lecture-seminar format, it examines important cases drawn from major cities around the world such as Mumbai, Paris, New York, Shanghai, and Detroit. Topics include megacities and megaslums, sustainable cities, "cybercities," and some of the most important planning interventions and visions from the past. The aim of the course is three-fold: To develop a critical reading of a selection of urban spaces, planning efforts, and texts; to provide a vocabulary of some of the major urban plans, ideas, and spaces: and to identify crucial issues that planners and designers now confront.    Prerequisites: None                     Semester     Instructor     Syllabus Link         Spring 2012  Syllabus                         Semester     Instructor     Evaluation Link

NYU.   This event is to honor the retirement of a faculty member and to celebrate the move of ECT to MAGNET, the Media And Games Network in Brooklyn. Attendance is by invitation only and we are currently at capacity, but if you would like to be added to the waitlist, please  contact us . Guest speakers include Constance Steinkuehler, Laurence Cocco, Francine Shuchat Shaw, Bob Ruderman, Jan Plass, and Christopher Hoadley.   Visit the event website for more information. About Us         Welcome to your hub for events, jobs, and announcements in instructional design, learning sciences, educational games and educational technology, sponsored by the Educational Technology programs at New York University 's Steinhardt School of Culture, Education, and Human Development .   NYU's ed tech programs include:   the Master's in Digital Media Design for Learning ,   the Master's in Games for Learning ,   the Ph.D. in Educational Communication and Technology , and   the Advanced Certificate in Digital Media Design for Learning . Permalink |          Email |     Share on: Facebook |       Twitter                                            DMDL "Past, Present and Future," May 18, 2013, Special Guest Speaker: Prof. Constance Steinkuehler - Highlights                              A Celebration of the ECT Program and Prof. Francine Shuchat Shaw    This event is to honor the retirement of a faculty member and to celebrate the move of ECT to MAGNET, the Media And Games Network in Brooklyn. It will be held on Saturday, May 18, 2013 at 5pm, and is by invitation only. This event is currently at capacity, but if you would like to be added to the waitlist, please contact us . Guest speakers include Constance Steinkuehler, Laurence Cocco, Francine Shuchat Shaw, Bob Ruderman, Jan Plass, and Christopher Hoadley.    Constance Steinkuehler       Constance Steinkuehler is an Associate Professor in Digital Media at the University of Wisconsin–Madison and co-directs the Games+Learning+Society (GLS) center at the Wisconsin Institute of Discovery and chairs their annual GLS Conference. Her research is on cognition and learning in commercial entertainment games and games designed for impact. In 2011-2012, she served as Senior Policy Analyst in the White House Office of Science and Technology Policy (OSTP) where she advised on national initiatives related to games. Policy work there included the coordination of cross-agency efforts to leverage games toward national priority areas (e.g. childhood obesity, early literacy, STEM education) and the creation of new partnerships to support an ecosystem for more diversified innovation in commercial and non-commercial games. She also played a central role in recent meetings through the Vice President’s office on videogames and violence.    Constance’s current research interests include neuroscience and games (particularly in the areas of attention and emotional and social well-being), learning analytics (informal scientific reasoning, problem-solving, and the role of failure), and mixed methods (game community discourse and literacy). Her work has been funded by the MacArthur Foundation, the National Academy of Education/Spencer Foundation, the Gates Foundation, and the National Science Foundation. She has published over twenty peer reviews publications on games and learning, three edited books three special issues of peer reviewed academic journals focused on the intellectual life of games, and the 2009 National Academies of Science report entitled Learning Science: Computer Games, Simulations, and Education. Current game titles under development include Tenacity and Crystals of Kaydor.    Constance has a PhD in Literacy Studies, an MS in Educational Psychology, and three Bachelor Degrees in Mathematics, English, and Religious Studies. Her dissertation was a cognitive ethnography of the MMOs Lineage I and II where she served as siege princess for the LegendsOfAden guild.                Professor Jan Plass introduces Constance Steinhkueler at the DMDL "Past, Present and Future" event on May 18, 2013    Permalink | Email | Share on: Facebook | Twitter          Watch Professor Constance Steinkuehler Complete Presentation at DMDL "Past Present and Future," on May 18, 2013       Laurence Cocco       Laurence Cocco is the Director of the Office of Educational Technology for the New Jersey Department of Education with the responsibility of supervising all federal and state educational technology initiatives. He is the NJ PARCC State Readiness Coordinator (Partnership for Assessment of Readiness for College and Careers), serves on the national PARCC Technology Committee, and chairs the PARCC Technology Readiness Working Group.    Many evenings, however, he can be found in World of Warcraft (WoW) conversing with fellow members of the educators’ guild Cognitive Dissonance on the educational value of WoW and other games. He conducts webinar interviews and panel discussions on educational gaming every third Thursday of the month at 9 PM ET for G.A.M.E. (Gamers Advancing Meaningful Education - http://g.a.m.e.shivtr.com/pages/webinarpage). Currently he’s working with guild members on developing an application to allow for the insertion of educational overlays into the existing high-quality commercial games that have captivated today’s students. The intent is to measurably enhance the learning and assessment opportunities for educators using such games in instruction.    Besides chairing the Thirteen/WNET Educational Services Advisory Committee, Laurence is also on the Board of Directors for the State Educational Technology Directors Association (SETDA - www.setda.org), and a Trustee of NJEDge.net, New Jersey’s higher education research and education network. His career path has included experiences such as Deputy Executive Director for New Jersey Network (former NJ PBS station), Senior Producer at Caucus: New Jersey, Senior Audiovisual Designer at Cosentini Information Technologies, Media Integration Project Director at Jersey City Public Schools, freelance photographer and independent video producer.    Laurence has a M.A. in Educational Communication & Technology from NYU. He is an Ed Tech and lifelong learning evangelist, looking to transform learning strategies through the incorporation of emerging technologies and brain-based learning theory.
